allTeachings.text: as a game master, how do I teach you the rules to shadowrun second edition so that you can run an adventure for me?  I want to be able to have you scan the full main rules instead of using the shortened ruleset?
Provide the Shadowrun Second Edition Core Rulebook
gritty and lethal, cinematic, or narrative-focused. SR2’s rules support a deadly game, but I can adjust tone (e.g., less focus on deadly damage if you want heroism).

Begin with core mechanics (dice rolls, combat, character creation) before diving into complex systems like the Matrix or rigging. SR2’s subsystems are dense, and incremental learning ensures accuracy.
Provide rulebook examples or create your own to illustrate mechanics. This helps me map rules to gameplay.
The full SR2 rulebook is extensive. If you’re transcribing or summarizing, focus on one chapter at a time (e.g., 20-30 pages) to avoid overwhelming either of us.
If you use house rules (common in SR2 to fix issues like TN scaling), list them upfront to avoid confusion with raw rules.
If you’re stuck, check SR2 discussions on Reddit or Shadowrun Wiki for clarifications, but always verify against the core rulebook. I can analyze these sources if you share them.
I can’t access the SR2 rulebook unless you provide it. My knowledge is based on general Shadowrun information and SR2-specific details from online sources, which may not cover the full rules.
I’ll only process rules you legally share. If you’re unsure about legality, I can work with summaries you write or public-domain SR2 info (though this may not cover the full rules).
SR2 rules differ from later editions (e.g., SR3 splits Quickness into Agility and Reaction, SR4 uses fixed TNs). I’ll stick to SR2 mechanics unless you request adaptations.

I summarize: “Actions use d6s equal to skill level, targeting a TN (base 4, modified by conditions). Successes are dice rolling TN or higher. Example: A hacker with Computer 5 rolls 5d6 vs. TN 6 to bypass a node.” I then ask, “Does this match the rulebook? Any modifiers I missed?”
We set up a run, like a datasteal in Seattle, with your character (e.g., an elf shaman) and NPCs I create using SR2 rules.
If you use any SR2 house rules (e.g., to simplify Matrix or cap TNs), mention them upfront.
I’ll ensure all mechanics are SR2-based, not later editions (e.g., SR3’s split attributes or SR4’s fixed TNs).

Even if uploads were possible, a 32MB+ PDF would likely exceed standard limits (e.g., 25–50MB for most platforms). The Shadowrun Second Edition PDF, especially if scanned with images, can be large due to its length and formatting.

“I understand that actions roll d6s equal to skill level against a TN (base 4, modified by conditions). Example: A hacker with Computer 5 rolls 5d6 vs. TN 6. Correct?” You can confirm or correct before sending the next section.
Any SR2 tweaks (e.g., capping TNs at 12) or strict rules-as-written.

I summarize: “Actions roll d6s equal to skill vs. a TN (base 4, modified by conditions). Successes are dice ≥ TN. Example: A rigger with Pilot 5 rolls 5d6 vs. TN 6, getting 2 successes.” I ask, “Is this correct? Ready for the combat rules?”
I’ll use only SR2 rules from your rulebook, avoiding later editions or simplified versions.
2 contacts; can call on 2d6 tribe members for help.
Roll 5d6 (Sorcery 5) vs. TN 4 (Average, per Skill Success Table, assuming no modifiers). Each die ≥4 is a success. Suppose I roll [6, 5, 3, 2, 1]: 2 successes.

If the shaman tries a skill like Demolitions (untrained), they default to Intelligence (4) via the Skill Web. Tracing Intelligence → Demolitions (1 step) adds +2 to TN (e.g., TN 4 becomes 6). Roll 4d6 vs. TN 6.
Let me know if my summary and example align with the rules or if I missed anything (e.g., dice pool usage, spell mechanics).
Provide the setting, run type, tone, and PC details (archetype or custom). Example: “A datasteal in Seattle, gritty tone, using the Street Mage.”

You encounter a guard. Using the Street Shaman’s Powerball 6 (Sorcery 5), I’d roll 5d6 vs. TN 4 (2 successes, as above). I need Combat rules to resolve the guard’s response.
Please share the Combat or Magic section next, confirm the adventure details, and let me know if the example is correct. If you have questions about extracting more text or anything else, I’m here to help!








I have an existing character created.  how do I make this available to you, so you can understand it?




Thank you for letting me know you have an existing Shadowrun Second Edition character! To make your character available to me so I can understand and use it for your adventure, you’ll need to share the character’s details in a structured format. Since I can’t accept direct file uploads or access external links, the best way is to copy-paste the character sheet or describe its key components (attributes, skills, gear, etc.) directly into our conversation. Below, I’ll guide you on how to share the character effectively, ensuring I understand it within the Shadowrun Second Edition rules (using the full rules from the document you provided, not a shortened version). I’ll also outline how I’ll use this information to run your adventure and address any follow-up steps.

How to Share Your Character
Your character sheet likely includes attributes, skills, gear, cyberware, spells (if magical), and other details created using the Shadowrun Second Edition priority system or archetype

If your character is in a digital file (e.g., a PDF or Word doc), open it and copy-paste the text. If it’s in your >32MB Shadowrun Second Edition PDF, extract the relevant pages using a PDF reader or OCR tool (like Google Docs, as you did before) and paste the character details.

I’ll read the attributes, skills, gear, etc., and confirm I understand them within the Shadowrun Second Edition rules. For example, I’ll verify that skills don’t exceed the starting cap (6) and that Essence/Magic align with cyberware.
Roll d6s equal to skill rating vs. a target number (e.g., TN 4 for Average tasks). Example: For your character’s Firearms 3, I’d roll 3d6 vs. TN 4 to shoot.

I’ll run a sample scenario to ensure I’m applying the rules correctly. Example: If your character is a mage casting Powerball 6, I’ll roll Sorcery (e.g., 5d6) vs. TN 4, noting successes. (I’ll need the Magic chapter for full spell mechanics.)
Body 6, Quickness 5, Strength 4, Charisma 3, Intelligence 4, Willpower 4, Essence 3.2, Magic 0, Reaction 5, Initiative 5 + 1d6
For Blitz shooting with the Ares Predator, I’d roll 7d6 (Pistols 7) vs. TN 4 (Average). If I roll [6, 5, 4, 3, 2, 1, 1], that’s 3 successes. (I’d need Combat rules for damage resolution.)
Initiative, actions, damage, and armor (likely pages 80–100) are essential for resolving fights. Example: I can’t calculate damage for your character’s attacks yet.
“Run a gritty datasteal in Seattle where my shaman infiltrates a Renraku lab. Use raw SR2 rules.”

I confirm: “Mist’s Sorcery 5 means 5d6 for Powerball vs. TN 4. I’ll roll for a test scenario: [5, 4, 3, 2, 1] = 2 successes. Correct?” I ask for Combat rules to resolve outcomes and set up the datasteal with Mist infiltrating a corp facility.

SR2 uses Essence (for cyberware) and Body Index (for bioware) to track character augmentation limits. Essence starts at 6 and is reduced by cyberware installations, while bioware affects the Body Index, which can lead to penalties if it exceeds the character’s Body attribute.

SR2 cyberware includes items like datajacks, wired reflexes, and cyberlimbs, with stats for Essence Cost, Price, Legality, Availability, and Street Index. Bioware, introduced in supplements like Shadowtech, uses Body Index instead of Essence.
SR2 uses dice pools (e.g., Combat Pool, Hacking Pool) and Initiative, which can be modified by cyberware (e.g., Wired Reflexes) or bioware (e.g., Synaptic Accelerator).

SR2’s Matrix rules govern cyberdecks and programs, which Shadowtech expands with Matrixware.
2. Shadowtech Gear Overview

Shadowtech introduces new headware (e.g., Softlink, Crypto Circuit), internals (e.g., Encephalon, Tactical Computer), Matrixware (e.g., MPCP, Hardening), and bodyware (e.g., Hydraulic Jack, Skill Hardwires). These expand on SR2’s offerings with more specialized or advanced options.

Most Shadowtech cyberware aligns with SR2’s Essence-based system. For example, Shadowtech’s Datajack (Level 1–4) offers tiered Essence costs (0.1–0.25) compared to SR2’s flat 0.2, allowing flexibility. Use Shadowtech’s tiered options as upgrades or alternatives.

Integrate bioware using Shadowtech’s Body Index rules. SR2’s core rules don’t cover bioware, so adopt Shadowtech’s rule that Body Index exceeding Body attribute causes stress (e.g., -1 to physical attributes per point over Body).

Shadowtech’s Matrixware (e.g., MPCP, Hardening) requires integrating with SR2’s cyberdeck rules. Treat these as cyberdeck components implantable in the body, using Essence costs and affecting deck performance (e.g., Hardening increases deck resistance to Black IC).

Shadowtech’s Encephalon (Levels 1–4) adds a Task Pool for mental tasks (e.g., +1 die per level). Integrate this by allowing the Task Pool to refresh like SR2’s other pools, usable for Knowledge skills or technical tasks.

Shadowtech’s tiered Skillwires (Levels 1–9) and Hardwires (Levels 1–10) expand SR2’s Skillwire system. Allow higher levels but increase Essence costs and Street Index to reflect rarity, aligning with Shadowtech’s pricing.
Shadowtech’s Legality codes (e.g., 3CB, 4P-CA) align with SR2’s permit system. Use SR2’s permit rules for restricted gear, requiring Street Index adjustments for black-market purchases.

Gear like Synaptic Accelerator (bioware) or Wired Reflexes (cyberware) boosts Initiative. Combine Shadowtech’s +1D6 per level for Synaptic Accelerator with SR2’s Wired Reflexes (+2D6 per level) but cap total Initiative dice to avoid overpowered characters (e.g., max +4D6).

Bioware like Tailored Pheromones (+1–2 to Social Tests) integrates seamlessly with SR2’s Social skill tests, using Shadowtech’s mechanics directly.
4. Handling Conflicts

SR2’s Datajack is 0.2 Essence; Shadowtech offers Levels 1–4 (0.1–0.25). Use Shadowtech’s as optional upgrades, with higher levels enabling faster data transfer (e.g., +1 to Matrix actions for Level 4).

GMs should introduce Shadowtech gear gradually, ensuring Availability and Street Index reflect their rarity. For example, Tactical Computers (Availability 12/60 days) require significant downtime or black-market contacts.
If you need specific gear mechanics (e.g., full rules for Crypto Circuit) or integration with other SR2 systems (e.g., magic, rigging), let me know, and I can expand the artifact.

Edges and Flaws, Group Karma Pool, and Called Shots. Below, I’ll confirm these rules as they apply to Shadowrun, Second Edition and provide a finalized rules selection artifact for our game. I’ll also note that the Shadowrun Companion for Second Edition (FASA 1996) has slightly different terminology and mechanics compared to Third Edition, so I’ll adjust accordingly.

In the Shadowrun Companion: Beyond the Shadows (Second Edition), Edges and Flaws are optional character traits that add advantages (Edges) or disadvantages (Flaws) to characters during creation. Edges provide bonuses (e.g., High Pain Tolerance reduces wound penalties, Ambidextrous lowers off-hand penalties), while Flaws impose penalties (e.g., Allergy causes reactions to specific substances, Combat Paralysis increases hesitation in fights). These are taken during character creation using the Priority System or Build Points (if using the optional point system).

Players can take up to 6 points of Edges and 6 points of Flaws. Each Edge costs Build Points (or requires balancing with Flaws in the Priority System), and each Flaw grants additional Build Points. For Second Edition, the Companion provides a list of Edges like Aptitude (bonus to a skill) and Flaws like Gremlins (tech malfunctions).

Adds depth to character backgrounds and encourages roleplay, with mechanical benefits or drawbacks. For example, a character with the Edge “Night Vision” can see better in low light, while one with the Flaw “Phobia” might panic in specific situations.

We’ll use the Edges and Flaws lists from the Shadowrun Companion (Second Edition, pp. 20–30). Players can select these during character creation, and I’ll ensure balance (e.g., no stacking excessive Flaws for points without roleplay consequences).

This optional rule allows the team to share a collective Karma Pool, in addition to individual Karma Pools, to represent teamwork and clutch moments. In Second Edition, the Karma Pool is a resource players use to reroll failed dice, buy successes, or avoid deadly outcomes.

The Group Karma Pool is calculated as the sum of all players’ individual Karma Pools divided by a factor (typically 4 or 5, GM’s choice). For example, if four players have Karma Pools of 2, 3, 2, and 1 (total 8), the Group Karma Pool might be 8 ÷ 4 = 2 points. Any player can spend Group Karma Pool points with team consensus, but it refreshes more slowly than individual pools (e.g., at the start of a new run or session).

This rule expands combat options by allowing players to target specific locations (e.g., head, leg, or a weapon) or aim for specific effects (e.g., bypassing armor, disarming). In Shadowrun, Second Edition, Called Shots are briefly mentioned in the core rulebook (p. 94) but expanded in the Shadowrun Companion for more detail.

We’ll use the Companion’s guidelines (pp. 54–55) for Called Shots, with a standard +4 TN modifier unless the target is exceptionally small (e.g., +6 for a specific item). I’ll adjudicate effects based on narrative and fairness (e.g., a headshot might increase Damage Level from M to S, but won’t instantly kill a major NPC).

We’ll use the Shadowrun, Second Edition core rulebook (FASA 1992) as the baseline, with its Priority System for character creation (Race, Magic, Attributes, Skills, Resources). Dice mechanics (d6 pools, target numbers, staging) remain standard.

The Second Edition Shadowrun Companion has fewer optional rules than the Third Edition version, focusing heavily on character creation (Edges/Flaws, alternative systems) and some combat tweaks. Rules like Otaku, free spirits, or expanded Matrix systems are absent or less developed, as they were introduced later.

You didn’t select other optional rules (e.g., Point-Based Character Creation, expanded Lifestyle rules, or alternative Initiative systems), so we’ll stick to core Second Edition mechanics for those aspects unless you specify otherwise.

Edges and Flaws, Group Karma Pool, and Called Shots. Additionally, you want to replace the core Shadowrun, Second Edition Matrix combat rules with those from Virtual Realities 2.0 (1997, FASA). I’ll integrate this change into our ruleset, explain how the Virtual Realities 2.0 Matrix rules work for clarity, and update the rules artifact to reflect your preferences.

Deckers in the Matrix roll Initiative using Reaction + Hacking Pool dice, modified by their cyberdeck’s Response Increase (e.g., +1d6 or +2d6). This is faster than meat-world Initiative, reflecting the speed of cyberspace. Hot ASIST interfaces (used by most deckers) add +1d6 to Initiative but risk biofeedback damage.

Deckers can “load” programs into their cyberdeck’s active memory (limited by Memory and MPCP ratings) and switch them strategically, mimicking a mage’s spell choices. For example, a decker might use Analyze to scout IC, then load Attack to fight it.

Edges and Flaws, Group Karma Pool, and Called Shots. You’re also using the Virtual Realities 2.0 (1997) rules for Matrix combat instead of the core Shadowrun, Second Edition Matrix rules, but you want to ignore tracking of programs for the Matrix rules. I’ll update the ruleset to reflect this change, explain what ignoring program tracking means for Virtual Realities 2.0 Matrix combat, and provide an updated rules artifact.

Program ratings (e.g., Attack 6, Sleaze 4) still apply for tests (e.g., rolling Computer + Hacking Pool with program bonuses), but we won’t track which programs are “active” or their memory costs. For example, a decker can use Attack to fight IC, then immediately use Analyze to scout, without managing memory.

Deckers can freely choose programs for each action without worrying about memory or load times. For example, they can use Attack to damage IC, Armor to resist damage, or Sleaze to avoid detection, all in the same run, without swapping programs.

To prevent deckers from becoming overpowered (since they have unlimited program access), I’ll assume their cyberdeck has a fixed set of programs (chosen at character creation, per VR 2.0’s program list, pp. 90–100) with reasonable ratings (e.g., 4–6, based on Resources). This avoids the need to track memory while maintaining game balance.

Edges and Flaws, Group Karma Pool, and Called Shots, and using Virtual Realities 2.0 (1997) for Matrix combat while ignoring program tracking. Now, you want to incorporate specific optional magic rules from Shadowrun, Third Edition (1998) related to spellcasting and spell learning. Since these rules come from a different edition, I’ll adapt them to fit the Shadowrun, Second Edition framework to ensure compatibility, explain how they work in our game, and update the rules artifact accordingly.

In Shadowrun, Third Edition (p. 181, core rulebook), an optional rule allows mages to cast a spell at a lower Force than its learned Force without incurring penalties (e.g., no increased Drain or target number). Normally, casting at a lower Force might increase Drain or complicate targeting, depending on the GM’s ruling. This rule makes spellcasting more flexible, letting mages conserve power for less challenging situations.
In Shadowrun, Second Edition (p. 130, core rulebook), spells are learned at a specific For

Drain is calculated based on the Force used, not the learned Force, using Second Edition’s Drain code (e.g., Mana Bolt’s Drain is (Force/2)M, so Force 3 has a Drain of 2M). No additional Drain penalties apply for casting at a lower Force.

Makes mages more versatile, allowing them to “dial down” spells for minor threats without risking higher Drain or failure. Fits well with Second Edition’s flexible Sorcery system and encourages strategic spellcasting.

Works seamlessly with Second Edition’s magic rules, as it’s a permissive rule rather than a mechanical overhaul. Complements Edges/Flaws (e.g., Edge: Focused Concentration reduces Drain) and Group Karma Pool (for rerolling failed Drain tests).
2. Characters Only Have to Learn a Spell Once

In Shadowrun, Third Edition (p. 180, core rulebook), the optional rule states that mages learn a spell once at a specific Force, and that spell can be cast at any Force up to the learned Force without needing to relearn it at different Forces. This contrasts with the default rule where spells are tied to their learned Force, and casting at a different Force might require GM approval or relearning.

In Shadowrun, Second Edition (p. 132, core rulebook), spells are learned at a fixed Force (e.g., Powerbolt 4), and mages typically don’t need to learn the same spell multiple times unless they want a higher Force (which requires relearning at full cost). Since Second Edition doesn’t explicitly require multiple learnings for the same spell, this rule is already somewhat implicit, but I’ll formalize it to match Third Edition’s intent:

A mage learns a spell (e.g., Fireball) at a chosen Force during character creation or advancement, paying the Karma cost (Force × 2 for most spells, per Second Edition, p. 148). Once learned, the spell is “known” and can be cast at any Force up to the learned Force without needing to learn it again. This is redundant with the first rule (casting at lower Force without penalty) but clarifies that the spell is a single entity, not multiple versions.

Reinforces the flexibility of the first rule, ensuring mages don’t face bookkeeping or cost barriers to casting spells at varying Forces. Simplifies spell management in Second Edition, where spell lists are already compact.

Aligns with Second Edition’s spellcasting system and integrates with Called Shots (e.g., targeting a specific area with a spell, +4 TN) and Edges/Flaws (e.g., Flaw: Spell Addiction might limit spell variety).
3. Improving a Spell’s Force Costs Only the Karma Difference

In Shadowrun, Third Edition (p. 180, core rulebook, optional rule), to increase a spell’s Force, a mage pays the difference in Karma between the current Force’s cost and the new Force’s cost. For example, improving a spell from Force 3 to Force 5 costs the Karma for Force 5 minus the Karma for Force 3. This reduces advancement costs compared to relearning the spell at full cost.

In Shadowrun, Second Edition (p. 148, core rulebook), learning a spell costs Karma equal to Force × 2 (e.g., Force 3 spell costs 6 Karma, Force 5 costs 10 Karma). Improving a spell’s Force typically requires learning it as a “new” spell at the higher Force, paying the full Karma cost (e.g., 10 Karma for Force 5). To adapt the Third Edition rule:
To increase a spell’s Force, the mage pays Karma equal to the difference between the new Force’s cost and the current Force’s cost, using Second Edition’s formula (Force × 2). For example:

Significantly reduces the cost of improving spells, making magical advancement faster and encouraging mages to enhance their key spells. Balances Second Edition’s high Karma costs while keeping magic potent.

Fits Second Edition’s Karma system with the adjusted formula. Synergizes with Group Karma Pool (e.g., spending to boost spellcasting tests) and Edges/Flaws (e.g., Edge: Magical Talent reduces Karma costs for magic skills).

Second Edition’s magic system (Sorcery, Conjuring, Drain) remains intact, with these rules modifying only spellcasting and learning. Spell effects, target numbers (e.g., Willpower for combat spells), and Drain codes (e.g., (Force/2)M) use Second Edition standards.

The Third Edition rules are more flexible than Second Edition’s rigid Force system, but adapting them with a modified Karma cost (Force × 1 for upgrades) prevents mages from becoming overpowered. I’ll monitor balance during play (e.g., ensuring Drain and opposition keep mages challenged).

Most gear stats (e.g., Concealability, Damage, Reach) are directly compatible with Second Edition (p. 96, core rulebook, for weapons; p. 104 for armor). However, some items (e.g., Super Stun Baton) reference Third Edition rules, so I’ll adapt them using Second Edition equivalents (e.g., stun weapon rules from p. 103, Second Edition).

The catalog includes Availability (e.g., 4/24 hrs) and Street Index (e.g., 1.5), which align with Second Edition’s gear acquisition rules (p. 238, core rulebook). These will be used as-is for gear purchases via Contacts or black-market deals.

Cyberware Essence costs and rules (e.g., Boosted Reflexes) match Second Edition (p. 144, core rulebook). I’ll include the listed cyberware but exclude the optional cyberware damage and repair rules (pp. 88–90), meaning cyberware functions normally without risk of combat damage or repair costs unless narratively specified by the GM.

The gear is potent (e.g., Laser Axe’s (STR)S damage), but Second Edition’s high-lethality combat and GM discretion (e.g., via Called Shots or enemy tactics) ensure balance. Edges/Flaws (e.g., Flaw: Allergy affecting hypo-allergenic gear) and Group Karma Pool (e.g., rerolling failed attacks) integrate well.

The Street Samurai Catalog (pp. 88–90) includes optional rules for cyberware taking damage in combat (e.g., a Called Shot to a cyberlimb, TN 8, might disable it) and repair processes (e.g., Street Doc tests, costs). These rules add complexity and risk to cyberware use.

Per your request, these rules are excluded. Cyberware (e.g., Cyberguns, Boosted Reflexes) functions as described without risk of damage from combat unless narratively appropriate (e.g., a plot-driven event). Repairs, if needed, will be handled via standard Second Edition healing or downtime rules (p. 112, core rulebook) without specific cyberware repair mechanics.

Players can choose gear from the Street Samurai Catalog during character creation (Resources Priority) or acquire it in-game via Contacts (p. 238, Second Edition). Section Two gear (p. 1, for police/security) may require higher Street Index or plot-driven access (e.g., a Fixer with corp connections).

The Super Stun Baton’s Third Edition reference (p. 103, SRIII) is replaced with Second Edition stun rules: targets resist 8S Stun with Body, successes reduce damage (p. 103, core rulebook). The baton’s 12-use limit and 1-hour recharge are retained.

Excluding damage/repair rules makes cyberware more reliable, fitting Second Edition’s focus on augmentation as a power boost. Essence costs (e.g., Boosted Reflexes Level 3, Essence 2.8) ensure balance.
Stick with Virtual Realities 2.0 (no program tracking) or simplify with core Second Edition rules?

Most cyberware stats (Essence Cost, Cost, Availability, Street Index, Legality) are compatible with Second Edition (pp. 144–150, core rulebook). Cybertechnology assumes Shadowrun, Second Edition and Shadowtech (1992), which our ruleset supports. For items with Shadowtech-specific rules (e.g., Hardening, Persona Module), I’ll use Second Edition equivalents or note GM discretion, as Shadowtech isn’t fully in our ruleset but is referenced.

Essence costs (e.g., Move-by-Wire Level 2, 3.85) and nuyen costs (e.g., Tactical Computer Level 1, 350,000¥) are used as listed. Higher-grade cyberware (alpha, beta, delta) from NPC profiles (pp. 74–79) is included with adjusted costs/Essence per Second Edition (p. 146, core rulebook: alpha = 80% Essence, 2× cost; beta = 60% Essence, 4× cost; delta = 50% Essence, 8× cost).

Availability (e.g., 8/2 weeks) and Street Index (e.g., 1.5) align with Second Edition acquisition rules (p. 238, core rulebook). Restricted items (e.g., Eye Gun, 6P-CC) require GM approval or black-market access.

Cybermancy (pp. 1, 9, 77–78) allows Essence below 0 (e.g., Six Million Nuyen Street Samurai, Essence -7.6; Cyberzombie, Essence -2.25) via ritual magic, sustaining life unnaturally. Given its experimental nature and narrative weight (e.g., Hatchetman’s transformation, pp. 3–9), I’ll include it as a GM-controlled option, not standard player access, to maintain balance and reflect its rarity (e.g., delta clinics, corporate backing). Cybermancy rules (p. 9, truncated) suggest significant psychological and social costs (e.g., Cyberzombie’s detachment, p. 78), which can tie to Edges/Flaws (e.g., Flaw: Socially Distant).

Cybertechnology includes bioware (e.g., Adrenal Pump, Synthacardium) in NPC profiles but not in the gear tables. Since Shadowtech introduced bioware and Cybertechnology assumes its use, I’ll include listed bioware with Shadowtech stats (p. 44, Shadowtech) or Second Edition approximations, noting Essence/Body Index costs.

Cybermancy’s rarity and ethical implications (e.g., Hatchetman’s existential crisis, pp. 3–9; Cyberzombie’s loss of humanity, p. 78) make it unsuitable for starting characters. It’s best as a narrative tool (e.g., a cybermanced NPC antagonist) or late-campaign option for players with corporate backing (e.g., Fuchi, p. 3). I’ll include it in the ruleset as a GM-controlled element, with Essence below 0 possible but requiring GM approval and roleplay consequences (e.g., Flaw: Loss of Empathy).

Cybertechnology’s cybermancy rules (p. 9, truncated) aren’t fully provided, but NPC stats (e.g., Cyberzombie, Essence -2.25) imply standard Second Edition Essence mechanics with magical augmentation. I’ll note that Essence below 0 incurs psychological/social penalties, enforceable via Edges/Flaws or GM discretion.

Players can select Cybertechnology cyberware during character creation (Resources Priority) or acquire it in-game via Contacts (p. 238, Second Edition). Restricted items (e.g., Eye Gun, 7P-CC) may require plot-driven access (e.g., a delta clinic contact). Higher-grade cyberware (beta, delta) is rare, requiring GM approval and significant nuyen.

Limited to GM-controlled scenarios to preserve balance and narrative weight. For example, a player nearing death (like Hatchetman, p. 3) could undergo cybermancy with corporate backing, gaining Essence < 0 but taking Flaws like Socially Distant or a corporate leash.

Cybertechnology’s flavor (e.g., Hatchetman’s story, pp. 3–9) can inspire campaign elements, like a run to steal delta-grade cyberware or infiltrate a Fuchi clinic. The Chrome Kings (pp. 74–79) can be NPCs (e.g., Cyberzombie as a corporate enforcer).

If you have Shadowtech, Fields of Fire, or other Second Edition sourcebooks, I can integrate their gear/rules. Also, any missing Cybertechnology pages (e.g., cybermancy rules details) to refine mechanics?

Shadowtech cyberware (e.g., Smartgun Link, Essence 0.5, 3,300¥; Muscle Replacement Level 2, Essence 2, 40,000¥) uses Second Edition mechanics (pp. 144–150, core rulebook). Stats (Essence, Cost, Availability, Street Index, Legality) are taken directly from Shadowtech (pp. 20–33). Higher-grade cyberware (alpha, beta, delta) follows Second Edition adjustments (p. 146: alpha = 80% Essence, 2× cost; beta = 60% Essence, 4× cost; delta = 50% Essence, 8× cost), consistent with Cybertechnology.

Bioware uses Body Index (e.g., Adrenal Pump Level 1, Body Index 0.5, 45,000¥) instead of Essence, per Shadowtech (pp. 34–45). Total Body Index cannot exceed Body Attribute (p. 46); excess causes health issues (GM discretion, e.g., Flaw: Chronic Pain). Bioware stacks with cyberware, but high Essence loss (cyberware) or Body Index (bioware) may trigger Edges/Flaws (e.g., Flaw: Cyber-Psychosis). Cybertechnology’s bioware (e.g., NPC profiles) uses Shadowtech stats.
Essence loss from cyberware reduces maximum Body Index (Max Body Index = Body Attribute – Essence Loss). For example, a character with Body 6 and 2 Essence loss has a max Body Index of 4.
Bioware heals like natural tissue (Second Edition healing rules, p. 112). Overloaded bioware (Body Index > Body) may require medical checks (Biotech skill, TN 6) to avoid complications.

Includes slap patches (e.g., Stim Patch Level 3, 150¥), medkits (e.g., Level 3, 900¥), and drugs (e.g., Kamikaze, +1 Quickness, 100¥). These are available per Shadowtech stats, using Second Edition acquisition rules (p. 238).
Orthoskin and dermal plating provide Ballistic/Impact armor (e.g., Orthoskin Level 2, Body Index 0.75, +2/+1, 45,000¥). Stacks with worn armor, per Second Edition layering rules (p. 103).

Gear like Synaptic Accelerator (bioware) or Wired Reflexes (cyberware) boosts Initiative. Combine Shadowtech’s +1D6 per level for Synaptic Accelerator with SR2’s Wired Reflexes (+2D6 per level) but cap total Initiative dice to avoid overpowered characters (e.g., max +4D6).

This optional rule allows the team to share a collective Karma Pool, in addition to individual Karma Pools, to represent teamwork and clutch moments. In Second Edition, the Karma Pool is a resource players use to reroll failed dice, buy successes, or avoid deadly outcomes.

Deckers in the Matrix roll Initiative using Reaction + Hacking Pool dice, modified by their cyberdeck’s Response Increase (e.g., +1d6 or +2d6). Program ratings (e.g., Attack 6, Sleaze 4) still apply for tests (e.g., rolling Computer + Hacking Pool with program bonuses), but we won’t track which programs are “active” or their memory costs. Drain is calculated based on the Force used, not the learned Force, using Second Edition’s Drain code (e.g., Mana Bolt’s Drain is (Force/2)M, so Force 3 has a Drain of 2M). No additional Drain penalties apply for casting at a lower Force.

Makes mages more versatile, allowing them to “dial down” spells for minor threats without risking higher Drain or failure. Fits well with Second Edition’s flexible Sorcery system and encourages strategic spellcasting.

In Shadowrun, Third Edition (p. 180, core rulebook), the optional rule states that mages learn a spell once at a specific Force, and that spell can be cast at any Force up to the learned Force without needing to relearn it at different Forces. This contrasts with the default rule where spells are tied to their learned Force, and casting at a different Force might require GM approval or relearning.

In Shadowrun, Second Edition (p. 132, core rulebook), spells are learned at a fixed Force (e.g., Powerbolt 4), and mages typically don’t need to learn the same spell multiple times unless they want a higher Force (which requires relearning at full cost). Since Second Edition doesn’t explicitly require multiple learnings for the same spell, this rule is already somewhat implicit, but I’ll formalize it to match Third Edition’s intent:

A mage learns a spell (e.g., Fireball) at a chosen Force during character creation or advancement, paying the Karma cost (Force × 2 for most spells, per Second Edition, p. 148). Once learned, the spell is “known” and can be cast at any Force up to the learned Force without needing to learn it again. This is redundant with the first rule (casting at lower Force without penalty) but clarifies that the spell is a single entity, not multiple versions.

Reinforces the flexibility of the first rule, ensuring mages don’t face bookkeeping or cost barriers to casting spells at varying Forces. Simplifies spell management in Second Edition, where spell lists are already compact.

Aligns with Second Edition’s spellcasting system and integrates with Called Shots (e.g., targeting a specific area with a spell, +4 TN) and Edges/Flaws (e.g., Flaw: Spell Addiction might limit spell variety).
3. Improving a Spell’s Force Costs Only the Karma Difference

In Shadowrun, Third Edition (p. 180, core rulebook, optional rule), to increase a spell’s Force, a mage pays the difference in Karma between the current Force’s cost and the new Force’s cost. For example, improving a spell from Force 3 to Force 5 costs the Karma for Force 5 minus the Karma for Force 3. This reduces advancement costs compared to relearning the spell at full cost.

In Shadowrun, Second Edition (p. 148, core rulebook), learning a spell costs Karma equal to Force × 2 (e.g., Force 3 spell costs 6 Karma, Force 5 costs 10 Karma). Improving a spell’s Force typically requires learning it as a “new” spell at the higher Force, paying the full Karma cost (e.g., 10 Karma for Force 5). To adapt the Third Edition rule:
To increase a spell’s Force, the mage pays Karma equal to the difference between the new Force’s cost and the current Force’s cost, using Second Edition’s formula (Force × 2). For example:

Significantly reduces the cost of improving spells, making magical advancement faster and encouraging mages to enhance their key spells. Balances Second Edition’s high Karma costs while keeping magic potent.

The Third Edition rules are more flexible than Second Edition’s rigid Force system, but adapting them with a modified Karma cost (Force × 1 for upgrades) prevents mages from becoming overpowered. I’ll monitor balance during play (e.g., ensuring Drain and opposition keep mages challenged).

Shadowtech introduces new headware (e.g., Softlink, Crypto Circuit), internals (e.g., Encephalon, Tactical Computer), Matrixware (e.g., MPCP, Hardening), and bodyware (e.g., Hydraulic Jack, Skill Hardwires). These expand on SR2’s offerings with more specialized or advanced options.

Shadowtech’s Matrixware (e.g., MPCP, Hardening) requires integrating with SR2’s cyberdeck rules. Treat these as cyberdeck components implantable in the body, using Essence costs and affecting deck performance (e.g., Hardening increases deck resistance to Black IC).

SR2’s Datajack is 0.2 Essence; Shadowtech offers Levels 1–4 (0.1–0.25). Use Shadowtech’s as optional upgrades, with higher levels enabling faster data transfer (e.g., +1 to Matrix actions for Level 4).
